posts.cooked:
As you know, WA is introducing in recent times several features that Signal already has but all of which are privacy-oriented.
Just think of the excellent and granular configuration on who can see your profile picture and info (everyone, my contacts, my contacts except, no one) or the fact that you can chat with numbers not in your address book without necessarily adding them to it. And now also the ability to hide your Online status from everyone! (check wabetainfo.com)

I think Signal needs to speed up the introduction of features (hide phone number, username) because WA is regaining share and users it had lost recently.
What do you guys think?

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
signalOne:

I think Signal needs to speed up the introduction of features (hide phone number, username)

They are long overdue. Not because WA is improving, Signal need to focus on its own strengts and not comparing itself continuously with another app that adds a feature (that happens all the time).

I propose a ban on UI changes (who are apparently a lot of work, and introduce a lot of new bugs to weed out) until this is finished.

if UI changes take time let alone stories, coins, and things like that. It‚Äôs clear that the more features you introduce, the more time you have to spend keeping up with them and fixing bugs, considering then that a lot of these things are, how shall I put it, futile and unnecessary, certainly a far cry from ‚Äúits own strengts.‚Äù
Just look at all the latest changelogs: just bugfixes and little else

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: I don‚Äôt think it matters. WhatsApp has billions of dollars, an army of developers, and Signal‚Äôs code is open-source. Most of the features WhatsApp has released in the last six months are identical to features Signal has had for a while, or close to it. I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if they‚Äôre just implementing Signal code to get features out so quickly.

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
Avitus:

I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if they‚Äôre just implementing Signal code to get features out so quickly.

Porting a feature to a completely different codebase is often more work than implementing it from scratch.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: I‚Äôm not saying they‚Äôre copy/pasting the code verbatim .

posts.name: SignalUser
posts.cooked:
Avitus:

I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if they‚Äôre just implementing Signal code to get features out so quickly.

I don‚Äôt think they just copy the code. They will adapt it a bit to their needs. Just because no one else can see your online status (Signal doesn‚Äôt even have this feature), doesn‚Äôt mean that Meta doesn‚Äôt log this data in detail and perfidiously assign it to your profile.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Whatsapp is getting dangerously close to Signal Off Topic
I‚Äôm not saying they‚Äôre copy/pasting the code verbatim .

Whatsapp is way more stable and has much much less bugs in the interface than Signal. I don‚Äôt think they copy any code.
But they copy features, as Signal did copy features from Whatsapp.

Don‚Äôt forget, Whatsapp was there years before Signal.

signalOne:

I think Signal needs to speed up the introduction of features (hide phone number, username) because WA is regaining share and users it had lost recently.

The main reason for not using WhatsApp is because it doesn‚Äôt protect your data from Meta. None of their features is built to stop them from collecting metadata. And I doubt they will ever implement this kind of protection. All the other ‚Äúprivacy‚Äù features are just cosmetics.

Andrea:

Don‚Äôt forget, Whatsapp was there years before Signal.

Technically, TextSecure came out only one year after WhatsApp. Also, WhatsApp didn‚Äôt invent group chat, read receipts or any of the other standard chat features.

posts.name: Aldrik KLEBER
posts.cooked:
There is no competition to do through software but through Real security. And this is done through a neutral gouvernance.

If the goal is to dominate the market security is not the good way. Because all the market don‚Äôt Ask for security.

Security for all will never exist‚Äôs, but making it accessible to all is very well done by signal.

So my view is to stop doing feature competition. Doing a good product continuously improving is more important

Wopfi:

Technically, TextSecure came out only one year after WhatsApp. Also, WhatsApp didn‚Äôt invent group chat, read receipts or any of the other standard chat features.

As far as I remember, TextSecure was SMS encryption only for at least the first two years. I‚Äôm not sure, but I believe 2012 or so they started to be a messenger at all, with the ability to send not only text, but also photos and other stuff.
So it would be more 2009 versus 2012.
But that is not my point anyways. WhatsApp exists for a very long time, without making design changes every year. So at least some parts of the code do not regularly change. That often gives software more stability.

Aldrik_KLEBER:

So my view is to stop doing feature competition. Doing a good product continuously improving is more important

This is a funny statement.
Because it‚Äôs more or less the philosophy of the Signal team, to add features over features to survive the competition. Adding stickers is one example, adding MobileCoin is another.

Unfortunately, Signal is not a security product, it‚Äôs a compromise between security and being suitable for the masses, by concentration on special aspects of security (like end-to-end encryption), and ignoring others (like increasing the attack surface year by year when implementing new features).

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Andrea:

Unfortunately, Signal is not a security product, it‚Äôs a compromise between security and being suitable for the masses

Signal‚Äôs mission is to bring E2E encrypted-by-default messaging to the masses. It would be impossible to do that at any real scale without the goofy stuff like stickers.

Signal‚Äôs mission is to bring E2E encrypted-by-default messaging to the masses. It would be impossible to do that at any real scale without the goofy stuff like stickers.

Sad but true. You can either maintain your dignity or you can appeal to the masses, but not both.
They will never open source their apps, they will never make the app really secure. WhatsApp and Facebook do not threaten Signal.

Avitus:

Signal‚Äôs mission is to bring E2E encrypted-by-default messaging to the masses

Hmm, no, not really. That is Whatsapp‚Äôs mission. They brought e2e by default to the masses, with the help of Moxie, who supported the implementation.

Signal Messenger

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
Andrea:
Avitus:

Hmm, yes, really; per their own website .

I know it‚Äôs written there. But ‚Äúmasses‚Äù are using Whatsapp, not Signal.
Signal should look for a new mission, because that one is taken.

You‚Äôre conflating Signal‚Äôs mission with ‚Äúmore people use WhatsApp‚Äù. WhatsApp, even before Facebook, was not created for the same reason Signal was. WhatsApp didn‚Äôt even do messaging when it first came out. Signal, from the start, even back when it was called TextSecure, has been about perpetuating E2EE communication.

Andrea:
Avitus:

WhatsApp‚Äôs mission is to harvest data for Facebook to sell ads.

Yes, they collect meta-data. But that is not new.

They collect more than metadata. Recall whenever it was in the last five years that they admitted WhatsApp creates shadow Facebook profiles using data from WhatsApp profiles so they can sell more ads.

Andrea:
Avitus:

Is there any proof of this or that it‚Äôs still true? Facebook says WhatsApp is E2EE, but they‚Äôve said a lot of things that were outright lies for the last 15 years too.

I can only give his statement here

Signal >> Blog >> There is no WhatsApp 'backdoor'

which he had repeated later on Twitter or Reddit or whereever.
I have not heard anything differently.

So your answer is ‚Äúno, there‚Äôs no proof‚Äù. Your source is a statement made five years ago from Moxie who has never worked for Facebook. Brian Acton, co-founder of WhatsApp, left Facebook because they lied to him about how they‚Äôd use WhatsApp, and that was after Moxie helped them implement E2EE.

Zuckerburg has lied under oath while speaking to Congress many times. Nothing Facebook says should be trusted.
